info.name: Azion | API Reference V3
info.description:
## Welcome to the Azion API ## Overview The Azion API is a RESTful API based on HTTPS requests. It allows you to integrate your systems with Azion's platform simply, quickly, and securely. This way, you can check, remove, or update existing settings besides creating new ones. In this documentation, you'll find instructions on how the Azion API works and what functionalities are available. The content is constantly updated. Make sure you verify if there are any updates or changes before performing any development in your application, even if you're familiar with the Azion API. --- ## **Requirements** Both HTTPS requests and responses must be in JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) format. All HTTPS requests and responses must follow these conventions. ### **Base URL** The base URL of the API that must be used is: [**https://api.azionapi.net/**](https://api.azionapi.net/) --- ## Features ### **HTTP methods** Each HTTP method defines the type of operation that will be run. | HTTP method | CRUD | Whole Collection (e.g. /items) | Specific item (e.g. /items/:item_id) | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | GET | Read | It retrieves the list of items in a Collection. | It retrieves a specific item in a Collection. | | POST | Create | It creates a new item in the Collection. | \- | | PUT | Overwrite/Replace | It replaces a whole Collection with a new one. | It replaces an item in a Collection with a new one. | | PATCH | Edit/Modify | It partially updates a Collection. | It partially updates an item in a Collection. | | DELETE | Delete | It deletes a whole Collection. | It deletes an item in a Collection. | --- ### **Status codes** The HTTP return code defines the status—successful or not—after the requested operation is run. | Status Code | Description | | --- | --- | | 200 OK | General status for a successful operation. | | 201 CREATED | Successfully created a collection or item, through POST or PUT. | | 204 NO CONTENT | Successful operation, but without any content to be returned to the Body. Generally used for DELETE or PUT operations. | | 207 MULTI-STATUS | A batch of operations were triggered by a single request, which resulted in different return codes when it was run, for some of the operations. The codes are displayed in the “status” field, in the body of the response, for each sub-batch of operations for whichever are applicable. | | 400 BAD REQUEST | Request error, such as invalid parameters, missing mandatory parameters or others. | | 401 UNAUTHORIZED | Error caused by a missing HTTP Authentication header. | | 403 FORBIDDEN | User doesn't have the permission to run the requested operation. | | 404 NOT FOUND | The requested resource doesn't exist. | | 405 METHOD NOT ALLOWED | The requested method isn't applicable with the URL. | | 406 NOT ACCEPTABLE | Accept header missing from the HTTP request or the header contains formatting or the version isn't supported by the API. | | 409 CONFLICT | Conflict generated in running the request, such as a request to create an already existing record. | | 429 TOO MANY REQUESTS | The request was temporarily rejected, due to exceeding the limit on operations. Wait for the time defined in the X-Ratelimit-Reset header and try again. | | 500 INTERNAL SERVER ERROR | Unintentional error, due to an unidentified failure in the request process. | ### **HTTP headers** All requests must be generated with the HTTP header specifying the desired code format for responses and the API version used. The current version of the API is `3` and the format is `application/json`. ``` Accept: application/json; version=3 ``` --- ### **Rate limit** The limit of operations that can be run via the API is defined by three HTTP response headers: \* **X-ratelimit-limit:** number of operations allowed in one time-frame. \* **X-ratelimit-remaining:** number of operations still available in one time-frame. \* **X-ratelimit-reset:** the date and time, in ISO 8601 format. It represents the point in the future when the time-frame will be closed and when the limits will, therefore, be reset. Example of HTTP response headers and a request: ``` Date: Thu, 02 Nov 2017 12:30:28 GMT X-ratelimit-remaining: 199 X-ratelimit-limit: 200 X-ratelimit-reset: 2017-11-02T12:31:28.675446 ``` In the example provided, 200 operations are allowed within a 1-minute time frame. Of those, there are 199 still available, because one has already been run. The total limit will be reset after 1 minute. When the X-ratelimit-limit is reached, or in other words, when the X-ratelimit-remaining reaches zero, the API will give the error, HTTP 429 TOO MANY REQUESTS. If your application receives this error, you'll need to wait until the time defined in X-ratelimit-reset has passed, to make another request. \* **X-ratelimit-limit by product** The X-ratelimit limit variation by product is: \* **Real-Time Purge:** 200 requests per minute; except for the Wildcard purge, which is 2000 a day. > The rate-limit values are based on the `client_id`. --- ### **Optional parameters** In this version, it's possible to include some optional parameters as part of the GET method. It can help and modify the form in which your data will be returned. You can combine these parameters to get the result you want. They are: | Parameter | Description | Accepted values | | --- | --- | --- | | order_by | Identifies which field the return should be sorted by. The default ordering is ascending. | Depending on the fields available from the endpoint structure. | | sort | Defines which ordering to be used: ascending or descending. | asc

desc | | page | Identifies which page should be returned, if the return is paginated. The default value is 1. | Page number. | | page_size | Identifies how many items should be returned per page. The default value is 10. | Desired number of items. | --- ### **Request example** You can use one parameter, or a combination. Check the example below, which uses all of them in the same request. ``` curl --location 'https://api.azionapi.net/domains?order_by=name&page_size=20&sort=desc&page=3' \ --header 'Accept: application/json; version=3' \ --header 'Authorization: Token 2909f3932069047f4736dc87e72baaddd19c9f75' ``` --- # Authentication types Operation authentication and authorization via Azion API are done through Tokens. The option through Personal Tokens is also available. The first step is to create the Token by authenticating a registered user on [Real-Time Manager](https://sso.azion.com/login). If you don't have an account, [check our documentation to create one](https://www.azion.com/en/documentation/products/accounts/creating-account/). If you're part of an enterprise account, refer to your account owner to create one. Read more: [Tools > Tokens](https://api.azion.com/#5226890c-6ca2-4c4f-b244-6330417d41d0) [Tools > Personal Tokens](https://api.azion.com/#f3247782-3bbe-4021-869a-6cd71eb975f6) --- ## Encoding Username and Password Only token creation and canceling operations are performed through the Basic Authentication method, with username and password. This action can be performed directly in the Postman API interface. You can create and revoke the token through the API itself, but you must encode your username and password in base64. Base64 encoding can be done from the command line on a Unix terminal: ``` $ echo 'user@domain:password'|base64 dXNlckBkb21haW46cGFzc3dvcmQK ``` --- ## Basic Auth Basic authentication involves sending a verified username and password with your request. 1. In the **Tools** folder, select **Token.** 2. Then, select `POST`/tokens. 3. In the **Authorization** tab, select **Basic Auth** from the **Type** dropdown list. 4. Enter your API username and password in the **Username** and **Password** fields. 5. Click **Send**. In the request **Headers**, the Authorization header passes the API a Base64 encoded string representing your username and password values Read more: [Tools > Tokens](https://api.azion.com/#40384d0d-164b-4496-a6af-208066843474)

item.name: Digital Certificates

header.description: Details about the type of return and version.
Authentication through the Token, previously created through the Token Creation endpoint.

query.description:
Identifies which property the return should be sorted by.
Accepted values: Any valid object property. Ex: name, id.

Defines whether objects are shown in ascending or descending order depending on the value set in order_by. The default value is asc.
Accepted values: asc, desc.

Identifies which page should be returned, if the return is paginated. The default value is 1.
Accepted values: int.

Identifies how many items should be returned per page. The default value is 10.
Accepted values: int.

request.description:
Use the GET method to list all existing digital certificates and CSRs registered to your account. The following table describes all digital certificate properties the GET commands may return. ### Digital Certificate Properties | Property | Type | Description | | --- | --- | --- | | id | int | ID of the digital certificate. | | name | string | Name of the digital certificate. Can be changed via API. | | issuer | string | Certificate Authority (CA) that issued the digital certificate. | | subject_name | array of string | List of domain aliases. | | validity | string | Date and time of expiration of the digital certificate in timestampz format.

For digital certificates issued by a CA and manually registered to Azion, renewal must be scheduled manually. | | status | string | Status of the certificate verification in the internal Azion Certificate Manager tool.

If the `"Pending"` status remains for too long, make sure to validate if the CNAMEs of the associated Domain are the same as those registered with the Domain Registar. | | certificate_type | string | May be `edge_certificate` for certificates managed or generated by Azion or `trusted_ca` for mTLS applications. | | managed | bool | `true` if the certificate is managed by Azion's Certificate Manager. | | csr | string | The Certificate Signing Request (CSR) to be submitted to a CA. | | certificate_content | string | Contents of the digital certificate. Can be changed via API. | > **Important**: Most properties on this table cannot be changed via API. See the **User-managed Digital Certificate Properties** table below for more details on which properties can be manually changed via POST/PUT/PATCH methods.

See the **Digital Certificate Properties** table above for more details.

request.description:
Use the POST method to create a new digital certificate. See the table below for more information on all available properties. ### User-Managed Digital Certificate Properties | Property | Type | Description | Accepted values | Required | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | name | string | Name of the Digital Certificate you want to create. | \- | Yes | | certificate | string | Complete SSL certificate provided by a certificate authority (CA).

Must begin in:
`-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----`Must end in:
`-----END CERTIFICATE-----`
Any line breaks, including after begin and before end certificate markers, must be indicated with a `\n` escape sequence. | Valid certificate. | Yes | | private_key | string | Complete RSA private key provided by a CA.

Must begin in:
`-----BEGIN RSA PRIVATE KEY-----`Must end in:
`-----END RSA PRIVATE KEY-----`
Any line breaks, including after begin and before end private key markers, must be indicated with a `\n` escape sequence. | Valid private key. | Yes |

request.description:
A Certificate Signing Request (CSR) is a form that is submitted to a Certification Authority (CA) for signing. The CSR is the first step in registering an SSL/TLS certificate. Use the CSR endpoint to create an encrypted Certificate Request with Azion, which can then be sent for signing to a CA. > **Important**: For GET and DEL methods, use the Digital Certificates endpoint. After being created, the CSR will become a Digital Certificate object. When a certificate is signed by a CA, you can use the PATCH method to update the certificate contents with the encrypted certificate and the private key received. See the table **User-Managed Digital Certificate Properties** below for more details. ### CSR Properties | **Property** | **Type** | **Description** | **Accepted values** | **Required** | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | name | string | Name of the CSR. | \- | Yes | | common_name | string | CNAME of the domain you want to sign in FQDN format. | \- | Yes | | country | string | Your organization's country. Must be an ISO-3166 two-letter country code. | \- | Yes | | state | string | Your organization's state. | \- | Yes | | locality | string | Your organization's city or county. | \- | Yes | | organization | string | Name of the organization. | \- | Yes | | organization_unity | string | Department or body of the organization responsible for the request. | \- | Yes | | email | string | Email of the department or body of the organization responsible for the request. | \- | Yes | | private_key_type | string | Type of private key requested.

Azion currently supports only the 112-bit security key type RSA 2048. | `"rsa_2048"` | Yes | | sans | array of string | List of domains that will use the certificate. Make sure to include all applicable DNS entries. | \- | Yes |

request.description:
Use the PUT method to overwrite a digital certificate. Although you can change a single property using the PUT method, you must pass all fields for the request to be completed.

> If you wish to update a CSR with a certificate and private key provided by a CA, opt for the PATCH method as it does not require extra mandatory fields. 
  
See the **User-Managed Digital Certificate Properties** table above for all available settings.

item.description:
The Digital Certificates API allows you to manage your existing SSL certificates and Certificate Signing Requests (CSR). See the description for each method for further details.

[See the documentation on Digital Certificates for more information.](https://www.azion.com/en/documentation/products/edge-application/digital-certificates/)

---

### Features

#### Let's Encrypt

> Available for GET | PATCH 
  

This feature is in early access. Contact [the Sales team](https://www.azion.com/en/contact-sales/) to enable it for your account.

> See the Domains POST endpoint to know how you can create a Let's Encrypt™ certificate. 
  

For GET commands, if you have a Let's Encrypt certificate, you may check its signing status via the `status` property.

**Warning:** Executing a PATCH command to change the certificate and private key of a Let's Encrypt certificate will override the certificate. Once this is done, Azion will no longer renew the certificate upon validity.

item.name: Token

header.description:
Basic authentication for creating the Token takes place via the “user@ domain: password” pair encoded in base64, sent in the HTTP request via the header “Authorization: Basic”.
For example, if the user is “user@domain” and the password is “password” the base64 encoding resulting from the string “user@domain: password” will be “dXNlckBkb21haW46cGFzc3dvcmQK” and the header to be sent will be:
e.g.: Authorization: Basic dXNlckBkb21haW46cGFzc3dvcmQK

request.description:
Use the POST method to create a new token. It uses base64 encoding to generate your authentication.

See more information on [Authentication types](https://documenter.getpostman.com/view/24994369/2s93Y3ug3d#authentication-types) > **Encoding Username and Password**.

header.description:
Basic authentication for creating the Token takes place via the “user@ domain: password” pair encoded in base64, sent in the HTTP request via the header “Authorization: Basic”.
For example, if the user is “user@domain” and the password is “password” the base64 encoding resulting from the string “user@domain: password” will be “dXNlckBkb21haW46cGFzc3dvcmQK” and the header to be sent will be:
e.g.: Authorization: Basic dXNlckBkb21haW46cGFzc3dvcmQK

Basic authentication for canceling the Token takes place via the “user@ domain: password” pair encoded in base64, sent in the HTTP request via the heading “Authorization: Basic ”.

For example, if the user is “user@domain” and the password is “password” the base64 encoding resulting from the string “user@domain: password” will be “dXNlckBkb21haW46cGFzc3dvcmQK” and the header to be sent will be:

e.g.:

Authorization:
Basic
dXNlckBkb21haW46cGFzc3dvcmQK

item.description:
Use the Domains API to create, read, update, and delete your domains. See the description for each method for further details.

[See the documentation on Domains for more information.](https://www.azion.com/en/documentation/products/edge-application/domains/)

---

### Features

#### Let's Encrypt certificates

> Available for POST | PUT | PATCH 
  

To create a Let's Encrypt™ certificate for your domain, you may add the following value to the request body:

| **Property** | **Value** |
| --- | --- |
| digital_certificate_id | `"lets_encrypt"` |

When this property is in the body of the request, Azion will create a new Digital Certificate and bind it to your domain.

**You must inform a valid CNAME list** when creating a domain with a Let's Encrypt certificate.

Use the Tools/Digital Certificates endpoint to check the status of the certificate.

[See the documentation on Let's Encrypt certificates for more information.](https://www.azion.com/en/documentation/products/edge-application/digital-certificates/#lets-encrypt-certificate)

This feature is in early access. Contact [the Sales team](https://www.azion.com/en/contact-sales/) to enable it for your account.

---

[Let's Encrypt](https://letsencrypt.org/) is a trademark of [Internet Security Research Group](https://www.abetterinternet.org/). All rights reserved.

request.description:
Use the POST method to create a new application. See the table below for more information on all available properties. ### Edge Application Properties | Property | Type | Description | Accepted values | Required | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | id | int | ID of your edge application. Obtain this value via GET request. Cannot be changed via API. | \- | No | | name | string | Name of your edge application. | \- | Yes | | delivery_protocol | string | Protocol or protocols used by the application. | `"http,https"`
`"http"` (default) | No | | http_port | array of int | The HTTP port or ports your application will use. Separate values by a comma. | `80` (default)
`8008`
`8080` | No | | https_port | array of int | The HTTPS port or ports your application will use. Separate values by a comma. | `443` (default)
`8443`
`9440`
`9441`
`9442`
`9443` | No | | minimum_tls_version | string | The minimum TLS version of your application. | `""` (default)
`"tls_1_0" "tls_1_1" "tls_1_2" "tls_1_3"` | No | | active | bool | Activates the edge application. Cannot be changed via API. | `true` (default) | No | | schema_version | int | RTM platform version. Cannot be changed via API. Contact sales to upgrade your RTM version. | \- | No | > Although the only required property when creating an edge application is `name`, Azion recommends that you create an application with a Default Origin and Default Cache Setting. See the tables below for details on all available settings in POST. ### Origins When you create a new edge application using a POST request, you can also set up a Default Origin in the same body. > The following properties are **exclusive to POST methods and will not appear in response bodies to GET requests** to the Edge Applications/Main Settings endpoint. Use the Edge Applications/Origins endpoints to view or modify Origins. | Property | Type | Description | Accepted values | Required | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | origin_type | string | Type of origin the application will draw data from. | `single_origin` | No. | | address | string | Domain name (FQDN) or IPV4/IPV6 of your origin. If your origin does not use standard ports (80/HTTP and 443/HTTPS), you can use the domain:port notation in this field. | \- | If origin_type is set. | | origin_protocol_policy | string | Protocols for connection to the origin. | `"preserve"` (default)
`"http"`
`"https"` | No | | host_header | string | Host header value that will be delivered to the origin. | `"${host}"` (default) | No | ### Cache settings When you create a new edge application using a POST request, you can also set up a Default Cache Setting in the same body. > The following properties are **exclusive to POST methods and will not appear in response bodies to GET requests** to the Edge Application/Main Settings endpoint. Use the Edge Application/Cache Settings endpoints to view or modify Cache Settings. | Property | Type | Description | Accepted values | Required | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | browser_cache_settings | string | Defines the behavior toward browser cache TTL. | `"honor"`(default)
`"override"` | No | | browser_cache_settings_maximum_ttl | int | Maximum TTL for browser cache. Default value: 0. | ≥ `0` and ≤ `31536000` | No | | cdn_cache_settings | string | Defines the behavior toward caching in Azion's edge nodes. | `"honor"`(default)
`"override"` | No | | cdn_cache_settings_maximum_ttl | int | Maximum TTL for Azion's cache. Default value: 60. | ≥ `0` and ≤ `31536000` | No |

request.description:
Aside from the properties described in the **Edge Application Properties** table above, use the PUT method to overwrite the default edge application settings and activate new modules and features. ### Modules and features The following properties are **exclusive to PUT and PATCH** methods. | Property | Type | Description | Accepted values | Required | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | debug_rules | bool | Activates the debug rules feature for Rules Engine in Edge Application.

[Contact sales to enable this setting for your account](https://www.azion.com/en/contact-sales/). | `true`
`false` (default) | No | | application_acceleration | bool | Activates the **Application Acceleration** module. | `true`
`false` (default) | No | | caching | bool | Activates the **Edge Caching** module. | `true` (default)
`false` | No | | device_detection | bool | Activates the **Device Detection** module. | `true`
`false` (default) | No | | edge_firewall | bool | Activates **Edge Firewall** for the application. | `true`
`false` (default) | No | | edge_functions | bool | Activates the **Edge Functions** module. | `true`
`false` (default) | No | | image_optimization | bool | Activates the **Image Processor** module. | `true`
`false` (default) | No | | l2_caching | bool | Activates the **L2 Caching** module.

[Contact sales to enable this setting for your account](https://www.azion.com/en/contact-sales/). | `true`
`false` (default) | No | | load_balancer | bool | Activates the **Load Balancer** module. | `true`
`false` (default) | No | | raw_logs | bool | Activates raw logs for the application. | `true`
`false` (default) | No | | web_application_firewall | bool | Activates **WAF** for the application. | `true`
`false` (default) | No | **IMPORTANT**: The properties described as not required have a default value, so if you don't pass them, the request will be completed with the default value, even if it replaces the value you had used previously.

request.description:
Use the POST method to create a new cache setting for an edge application. See the table below for more information on all available properties. ### Cache Settings Properties | Property | Type | Description | Accepted values | Required | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | id | int | ID of your edge application. Obtain this value via GET request. Cannot be changed via API. | \- | No | | name | string | Name of your cache setting. | \- | Yes | | browser_cache_settings | string | Defines the behavior toward browser cache TTL. | `"honor"` (default)
`"override"` | No | | browser_cache_settings_maximum_ttl | int | Maximum TTL for browser cache. Default value: 0. | `0` ≤ `value` ≥ `31536000` | No | | cdn_cache_settings | string | Defines the behavior toward caching in Azion's edge nodes. | `"honor"` (default) `"override"` | No | | cdn_cache_settings_maximum_ttl | int | Maximum TTL for Azion's cache. Default value: 60. | `60` ≤ `value` ≥ `31536000` | No | | cache_by_query_string | string | Defines how you want the content to be cached according to variations of Query String in your URLs. Requires the Application Acceleration module. | `"ignore"` (default)
`"whitelist"`
`"blacklist"`
`"all"` | No | | query_string_fields | array of strings | Distinguishes which cookies will/will not be cached depending on the Cache by Query String policy. | \- | No | | enable_query_string_sort | bool | Considers objects with the same query strings as the same cached file regardless of the order of the fields. | `true`
`false` (default) | No | | cache_by_cookie | string | Defines how you want the content to be cached according to variations of Cookies. Whitelist and Blacklist options require the Application Acceleration module. | `"ignore"` (default)
`"whitelist"`
`"blacklist"`
`"all"` | No | | cookie_names | array of strings | Distinguishes which cookies will/will not be cached depending on the Cache by Cookie policy. | \- | No | | adaptive_delivery_action | string | Defines if Azion should keep device-based variations of objects in cache based on existing device groups. | `"ignore"` (default)
`"whitelist"` | No | | device_group | array of strings | Defines which device groups are included in adaptive delivery. Must be the ID of a valid device group. | \- | No | | l2_caching_enabled | bool | Enables L2 Caching to reduce the traffic to the origin and increase performance and availability. Requires the L2 Caching module. | `true`
`false` (default) | No | | l2_region | string | Sets the region for the L2. Requires the L2 Caching module. | `null` (default)
`"sa-brazil"`
`"na-united-states"` | No | | is_slice_configuration_enabled | bool | Enables the use of byte-range requests by slicing files and caching content on demand. | `true false` (default) | | | is_slice_edge_caching_enabled | bool | Sliced content is cached at the edge. | `true`
`false` (default) | No | | is_slice_l2_caching_enabled | bool | Sliced content is cached at the L2. Requires the L2 Caching module. | `true`
`false` (default) | No | | slice_configuration_range | int | Defines the byte range of cached content.

[Contact sales if you wish to change this value](https://www.azion.com/en/contact-sales/). | `1024` (default) | No | | enable_stale_cache | bool | Defines if Azion caches stale content. | `true` (default)
`false` | No | | enable_caching_for_post | bool | Defines if Azion caches POST requests. | `true`
`false` (default) | No | | enable_caching_for_options | bool | Defines if Azion caches OPTIONS requests. | `true`
`false` (default) | No |

request.description:
Use the POST method to create a new origin for your edge application. See the table below for more information on all available properties. ### Origins Properties | Property | Type | Description | Accepted values | Required | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | origin_id | int | ID of your origin. Obtain this value via GET request. Cannot be changed via API. | \- | No | | origin_key | string | Key of your origin. Obtain this value via GET request. Cannot be changed via API. | \- | No | | name | string | Name of your origin. | \- | Yes | | host_header | string | Host header value that will be delivered to the origin. | `"${host}"` (default) | Yes | | addresses | array of object | List of addresses linked to the origin. Must be a JSON object. | See **Addresses Properties** table. | Yes | | origin_type | string | Identifies the source of a record. | `"single_origin"` (default)
`"load_balancer"`
`"live_ingest"` | No | | origin_protocol_policy | string | Protocols for connection to the origin. | `"preserve"` (default)
`"http"`
`"https"` | No | | is_origin_redirection_enabled | boolean | Whether origin redirection is used or not. | `true`
`false` (default) | No | | method | string | Method used to distribute incoming network traffic among computing resources. | `"ip_hash"` (default)
`"least_connections"`
`"round_robin"` | No | | origin_path | string | Path to be appended to the URI when forwarding the request to the origin. Leave it in blank to use only the URI. | \- | No | | connection_timeout | int | Amount of time the connection will wait before timing out. | `60` (default) ≤ `75` | No | | timeout_between_bytes | int | The amount of time a system waits for the next byte of data to arrive before timing out. | `120` (default) | No | | hmac_authentication | bool | Whether HMAC Authentication is used or not. | `true`
`false` (default) | No | | hmac_region_name | string | HMAC region name. | \- | No | | hmac_access_key | string | HMAC access key value. | \- | No | | hmac_secret_key | string | HMAC secret key value. | \- | No | ### **Addresses Properties** The `addresses` property takes an array of JSON objects as accepted values. The following table describes the properties available for the objects. | Property | Type | Description | Accepted values | Required | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | address | string | The domain name (FQDN) or IPV4/IPV6 from which Azion draws content. | \- | Yes | | weight | int | Assign a number from 1 to 10 to determine how much traffic a server can handle.

Available only for the **Load Balancer** origin type. | `null` (default)
`1` < `value` ≤ `10` | No | | server_role | string | Origins set as backup servers will only receive HTTP requests if all primary servers are unavailable.

Available only for the **Load Balancer** origin type and **Least Connections** or **Round Robin** methods. | `"primary"` (default)
`"backup"` | No | | is_active | bool | Activate or deactivate an origin.

Available only for the **Load Balancer** origin type. | `true` (default) | false |

`"request"` | Yes | | criteria | array of array | The criteria that will trigger the execution of the rule. | See **Criteria** table. | Yes | | behaviors | array of objects | The behaviors that will be executed upon meeting the criteria. | See **Behaviors** table. | Yes | | is_active | bool | Defines if the rule is active or inactive. | true (default) | false | | order | int | Order the rule is executed, from first to last. | \- | No | | description | string | An optional description for users to identify the rule.

Must not exceed 1000 characters.

This field does not accept 4-byte unicode characters. | \- | No | ### Criteria | Property | Type | Description | Accepted values | Required | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | variable | string | Variable of the criteria. | See the **List of Variables** table for possible values. | Yes | | operator | string | Operator for the behavior. | See the **List of Operators** table for possible values. | Yes | | conditional | string | Type of conditional logic applied. | `if`
`and`
`or` | Yes | | input_value | string | Argument field. | \- | Yes\* | > **Note:** The `input_value` property may be removed from the body of the request depending on the chosen operator. See the **List of Operators** table for more information on which operators do not take an argument. #### List of Variables | Name/value | Description | Request Phase | Response Phase | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | `${arg_param}` | The value of the parameters on the query string. | Yes | Yes | | `${args}` | All values and parameters on the query string. | Yes | Yes | | `${cookie_name}` | The value of the cookie. | Yes | Yes | | `${device_group}` | Name of device group. Must be the name of a valid device group. | Yes | Yes | | `${geoip_city_continent_code}` | 2-letter continent code, using the geolocation base geoip_city. | Yes | Yes | | `${geoip_city_country_code}` | 2-letter country code, using the geolocation base geoip_city. | Yes | Yes | | `${geoip_continent_code}` | Name of the continent, using the geolocation base geoip_city. | Yes | Yes | | `${geoip_city_country_name}` | Name of the country, using the geolocation base geoip_city. | Yes | Yes | | `${geoip_city}` | Name of the city, using the geolocation base geoip_city. | Yes | Yes | | `${geoip_country_code}` | 2-letter country code, using the geolocation base geoip_country. | Yes | Yes | | `${geoip_country_name}` | Name of the country, using the geolocation base geoip_country. | Yes | Yes | | `${geoip_region_name}` | Name of the country, using the geolocation base geoip_region. | Yes | Yes | | `${geoip_continent_code}` | 2-letter continent code. | Yes | Yes | | `${geoip_region}` | 2-letter region code. | Yes | Yes | | `${host}` | In order of precedence: the host name of the request line, or the value of the Host header of the request, or the name of the server serving the request. | Yes | Yes | | `${http_header}` | The value of the HTTP header field. The header must be in lowercase and any hyphens must be converted to underscore. | Yes | Yes | | `${remote_addr}` | The IP address of the client performing the HTTP request. | Yes | Yes | | `${remote_user}` | The username provided by basic authentication, if any. | Yes | Yes | | `${request}` | Complete request query. | Yes | Yes | | `${request_body}` | Arguments sent in the body of the request. | Yes | Yes | | `${request_method}` | The HTTP method of the request. | Yes | Yes | | `${request_uri}` | The complete URI of the request, with arguments (query string). | Yes | Yes | | `${scheme}` | Scheme (protocol) of the request. | Yes | Yes | | `${sent_http_header}` | The value of the HTTP response header field. The header must be in lowercase and any hyphens must be converted to underscore. | No | Yes | | `${status}` | Status code of the response. | No | Yes | | `${upstream_addr}` | The IP address and port of the queried origin for obtaining the response. If many origins are consulted during the processing of the request, the addresses will be separated by a comma. | No | Yes | | `${upstream_cookie_name}` | Value of cookie name sent by the origin in the Set-Cookie header. | No | Yes | | `${upstream_http_header}` | Value of the header sent by the origin. The header must be in lowercase and any hyphens must be converted to underscore. | No | Yes | | `${upstream_status}` | Status code of the origin response sent to RTM. If many origins are consulted while the request is processed, the status codes will be separated by a comma. | No | Yes | | `${uri}` | The normalized (urldecoded) URI of the request. | Yes | Yes | #### List of Operators | Name/value | Description | | --- | --- | | `is_equal` | The value of the variable is exactly the same as the argument. | | `is_not_equal` | The value of the variable isn’t the same as the argument. | | `starts_with` | The value of the variable starts with the argument. | | `does_not_start_with` | The value of the variable doesn’t start with the argument. | | `matches` | The value of the variable matches the regular expression entered as an argument. | | `does_not_match` | The value of the variable doesn’t match the regular expression entered as an argument. | | `exists` | The variable has a defined value. Does not take an argument. | | `does_not_exist` | The variable doesn’t have a defined value. Does not take an argument. | ### Behaviors | Property | Type | Description | Required | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | name | string | Name of the behavior. | Yes | | target | string | Argument field. | Yes\* | > **Note:** The `target` property may be removed from the body of the request or set to `null` depending on the chosen behavior. Does not take an argument. | Yes | No | | capture_match_groups | Stores in a temporary variable the result of capturing correspondence groups defined by a regex applied to one of the available HTTP request fields. See the Capture Match Groups Properties table below for available target values. | Yes | No | | deliver | Finishes processing the request and delivers the content to the user, without executing any of the rules added later. Does not take an argument. | Yes | Yes | | deny | Delivers a 403 Forbidden page to the user. Ends the request processing. Does not take an argument. | Yes | No | | enable_gzip | Enables Gzip data compression, if supported by the user’s browser. Does not take an argument. | Yes | Yes | | filter_request_cookie | Removes a cookie from the request header that would be sent to the origin. | Yes | No | | filter_response_cookie | Removes a cookie from the request header that would be sent to the user. | No | Yes | | filter_request_header | Removes a request header that would be sent to the origin. | Yes | No | | filter_response_header | Removes a response header that would be sent to the user. | No | Yes | | forward_cookies | Forwards the Set-Cookie header received from the origin to the user. Does not take an argument. | Yes | No | | no_content | Delivers a 204 No Content status code. Does not take an argument. | Yes | No | | optimize_images | Activates Image Processor. Does not take an argument. | Yes | No | | redirect_http_to_https | Redirects the HTTP request to the respective HTTPS URL. | Yes | No | | redirect_to_301 | Redirects the user to another URL entered as an argument, returning the status code 301 Moved Permanently. | Yes | Yes | | redirect_to_302 | Redirects the user to another URL entered as an argument, returning the status code 302 Found. | Yes | Yes | | rewrite_request | Modifies the resource path that will be requested for the origin. | Yes | No | | run_function | Runs a function created using Edge Functions. Must be the ID of an instantiated function in the application. | Yes | Yes | | set_cache_policy | Assigns the cache policy that should be used for the request. | Yes | No | | set_cookie | Adds a cookie and policies in the Set-Cookie response header. | No | Yes | | set_origin | Assigns an origin that must be consulted by the Intelligent Edge. | Yes | No | ##### Capture Match Groups Properties For the Capture Match Groups behavior, the `target` property becomes an object that takes the following variables. | Property | Type | Description | Accepted values | Required | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | captured_array | string | Temporary variable that stores captured strings. | \- | Yes | | subject | string | The HTTP request variable from where you want to capture a string. | `${variable}` | Yes | | regex | string | The regular expression to match the strings against. | Regular expression | Yes |

item.description:
Use the Rules Engine API to create, read, update, and delete rules in your edge applications. See the description for each method for further details.

[See the documentation on Rules Engine for more information.](https://www.azion.com/en/documentation/products/edge-application/rules-engine/)

The Edge Applications API allows you to create, list, update, or delete your existing applications.

[See the documentation on Edge Application for more information.](https://www.azion.com/en/documentation/products/edge-application/)

---

### Features

#### Simultaneous multiport

> Available for POST | PATCH | PUT 
  

If you create an edge application without setting the HTTP/HTTPS ports, the default ports are automatically set to `80` for HTTP and `433` for HTTPS.

With simultaneous multiport, you can set as many ports as you wish for either protocol by adding the desired ports to an array. You can also configure ports different from the default ones.

Make sure that the protocols you wish to set is defined in the `delivery_protocol` variable.

The ports available for HTTP and HTTPS are:

| **Property** | **Possible array values** |
| --- | --- |
| **http_port** | 80, 8080, 8008 |
| **https_port** | 443, 8443, 9440, 9441, 9442, 9443 |

[Contact our Sales team to enable this feature for your account.](https://www.azion.com/en/contact-sales/)

---

#### Debug Rules

> Available for PUT | PATCH 
  

You can enable the option to debug rules created with Rules Engine in your application. When active, data on executed rules will be available via GraphQL, Data Streaming or Real-Time Events. [See the guide on how to debug rules created with Rules Engine for more information.](https://www.azion.com/en/documentation/products/guides/debug-rules/)

| **Property** | **Value** |
| --- | --- |
| debug_rules | `true` |

[Contact our Sales team to enable this feature for your account](https://www.azion.com/en/contact-sales/).

item.description:
The [Edge Functions](https://www.azion.com/en/documentation/products/edge-application/edge-functions/) API allows you to manage your edge functions on the Azion platform.  
Edge Functions are functions that run at the edge of the network, with low latency, helping you to build fast and secure applications.  
They can be instantiated in edge applications and in edge firewall configurations.

item.description:
If you need to delete an object from the Edge Caching or L2 Caching layers before time-out, you can use the Real-Time Purge API. 
If desired, integrate the Azion API with your CMS to automate any content update process.

request.description:
Use the POST method to create a new rule set for an edge firewall. ## Rules properties | Property | Type | Description | Accepted values | Required | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | id | int | ID of your rule. Obtain this value via GET request. Can't be changed via API. | \- | No | | name | string | Name of the Rule Set being created | \- | Yes | | criteria | JSON | The beginning (conditional `If:`) of the Rule Set. Example: `if {hostname} is equal {myDomain.com}...` | \- | Yes | | behavior | JSON | The payload (command `Then:`) of the Rule Set. Example `... Then: Deny` | \- | Yes | | description | string | An optional description for users to identify the rule.

Must not exceed 1000 characters.

This field doesn't accept 4-byte unicode characters. | \- | No | | is_active | bool | Defines if the rule is active or inactive. | true (default) | false | | order (confirmar) | int | Order the rule is executed, from first to last. | \- | No | ## Criteria | Property | Type | Description | Accepted values | Required | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | variable | string | Variable of the criteria. | See the **List of Variables** table for possible values. | Yes | | operator | string | Operator for the behavior. | See the **List of Operators** table for possible values. | Yes | | conditional | string | Type of conditional logic applied. | `if`
`and`
`or` | Yes | | input_value | string | Argument field. | \- | Yes\* | > **Note:** The `input_value` property may be removed from the body of the request depending on the chosen operator. See the **List of Operators** table for more information on which operators do not take an argument. ## List of operators | Name/value | Description | | --- | --- | | `is_equal` | The value of the variable is exactly the same as the argument. | | `is_not_equal` | The value of the variable isn’t the same as the argument. | | `starts_with` | The value of the variable starts with the argument. | | `does_not_start_with` | The value of the variable doesn’t start with the argument. | | `matches` | The value of the variable matches the regular expression entered as an argument. | | `does_not_match` | The value of the variable doesn’t match the regular expression entered as an argument. | | `exists` | The variable has a defined value. Does not take an argument. | | `does_not_exist` | The variable doesn’t have a defined value. Does not take an argument. | ## Behaviors Indicated by the `Then:` operator. | Property | Type | Description | Required | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | name | string | Name of the behavior. | Yes | | target | string | Argument field. | Yes\* | > **Note:** The `target` property may be removed from the body of the request or set to `null` depending on the chosen behavior. See the **List of Behaviors** table for more information on which behaviors do not take an argument. # List of behaviors | Name | Value | | --- | --- | | Deny (403 Forbidden) | deny | | Drop (Close Without Response) | drop | | Set Rate Limit | set_rate_limit | | Set WAF Rule Set | set_waf_rule_set | | Run Function | run_function | | Tag Event | tag_event |

request.description:
Use the POST method to create a new Intelligent DNS Record. See the table below for more information on all available properties. | Property | Type | Description | Accepted values | Required | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | record_type | string | Definition of the type of record that'll be used. Accepts up to 10 characters. | \- | Yes | | entry | string | Accepts up to 250 characters. | \- | No | | answers_list | string, array | Response to the record being registered. Accepts values according to the type of `record_type` chosen. | \- | Yes | | ttl | int | Time a response can be cached for on a resolver server. Defined in seconds. | \- | Yes | | policy | string | Specifies which policy should be considered while resolving requests answered by this record entry.
You can use weighted policies with `A`, `AAAA`, `CNAME`, `ANAME`, and `MX` entries. | `simple`
`weighted` | No | | weight | int | Weight for the record. Can be specified when using the `policy` property with the `weighted` value. When you choose 0, Intelligent DNS stops using this record. | `≤ 255` | No | | description | string | Used to differentiate records with the same _Name_ and _Type_. | \- | No | According do the type of `record_type` you choose, the accepted values for `answers_list` have specific restrictions. See them in the table below. | Type | Restriction rule | Example | | --- | --- | --- | | A | Must be in IPv4 format. | 192.209.210.67
198.199.105.93 | | AAAA | Must be in IPv6 format. | 2800:3f0:4001:815::2004 | | ANAME | Must be in FQDN format. | 32082s.ha.azioncdn.net | | CAA | The value of the response must follow the format \[FLAG\] \[TAG\] “\[VALUE\]”. It isn't possible to register a CAA type record when the zone already has a CNAME type record. | “ca.example.com”
“ca.example.net; account=123456 | | CNAME | Must be in FQDN format. Only point it to another domain name, never an IP address. | example.com | | DS | \- | \- | | MX | Must be in the format \[PRIORITY\] \[ADDRESS\]. | 10 mailserver.example.com | | NS | Must be in FQDN format or an IP address. | ns1.aziondns.net | | PTR | Reverse zones lined to IPv6 addresses follow other rules. | [www.example.com](http://www.example.com) | | SRV | The record name must have the following format: ‘_service._protocol.name’. | 0 60 5060 bigbox.example.com | | TXT | Limited to 100 characters. | “printer=lpr5” |

Use the PUT method to overwrite an Intelligent DNS record. Although you can change a single property using the PUT method, you must pass all fields for the request to be completed.

**IMPORTANT**: The properties described as **not required** have a default value, so if you don't pass them, the request will be completed with the default value, even if it replaces the value you had used previously.

**Warning**: this action can't be undone.

request.description:
Use the POST method to create a new data streaming. See the table below for more information on all available properties. ### Data Streaming Properties | Property | Type | Description | Accepted values | Required | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | name | string | Name of the data streaming you want to create. | \- | Yes | | template_id | int | Identifier template of one of the default templates that you want to use with the new data streaming.

You can also use `template_model` to insert a custom template with a set of specific variables, instead of a default model. Find out more on the **POST Create new custom template** endpoint. | `2` (Edge Applications Event Collector)
`4` (WAF Event Collector)
`86` (Edge Functions Event Collector)
`184` (Edge Applications + WAF Event Collector)
`251` (Activity History Collector) | Yes | | data_source | string | Data source from which you want to stream your data. | `http` (Edge Applications, default)
`waf` (WAF Events)
`cells_console` (Edge Functions)
`rtm_activity` (Activity History) | No | | active | bool | Status of your data streaming. | `true` (default)
`false` | No | | endpoint | json | Endpoint to which you want to stream your data.This field must be filled out with different properties, according to the chosen endpoint type.

See the **Data Streaming Endpoints** table below for all endpoint options. | `"endpoint": { }`

Add `endpoint_type` + specific variables for the chosen endpoint. | Yes | | domain_ids | int, array | Domain identifiers that you want to associate to the new data streaming. | \- | Yes\* | | all_domains | bool | Used to associate all domains in your account to the new data streaming.

If you pass this field as true, the mandatory parameter `domain_ids` can be passed as an empty list. | `true`
`false` (default) | No\* | | sampling_percentage | int | **To use this feature,** [**contact the sales team**](https://www.azion.com/en/contact-sales/) **to activate it in your account.**

If you pass `all_domains` as `true`, you can define a sampling percentage to receive data collected from your account randomly. | from `0` to `100` | No | > \*Not used with the `rtm_activity` data source. **Note**: If you use the `rtm_activity` **data_source**, you can't associate domains. Thus, you don't need to send the **domain_ids** and **all_domains** fields. ### Data Streaming Endpoints During the process of creating or updating a data streaming, different endpoints are available for use. The following table describes the endpoints that may be used and the properties that must be informed. Use the POST method to create a new data streaming with the specific HTTP/HTTPS Standard endpoint. It also allows you to include a payload, with customized `format`, `log line separator`, and `max size`, and up to 5 headers. See the table below for more information on all available properties. ### Data Streaming HTTP/HTTPS Standard endpoint Properties | Property | Type | Description | Accepted values | Required | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | name | string | Name of the data streaming you want to create. | \- | Yes | | template_id | int | Identifier template of one of the default templates that you want to use with the new data streaming.

You can also use `template_model` to insert a custom template with a set of specific variables, instead of a default model.

Find out more on the **POST Create new custom template** endpoint. | `2` (Edge Applications Event Collector)
`4` (WAF Event Collector)
`86` (Edge Functions Event Collector)
`184` (Edge Applications + WAF Event Collector)
`251` (Activity History Collector) | Yes | | data_source | string | Data source from which you want to stream your data. | `http` (Edge Applications, default)
`waf` (WAF Events)
`cells_console` (Edge Functions)
`rtm_activity` (Activity History) | No | | active | bool | Status of your data streaming. | `true` (default)
`false` | No | | endpoint | json | Endpoint to which you want to stream your data. | `"endpoint": { }`

Add `endpoint_type` + specific variables for the chosen endpoint. | Yes | | endpoint_type | string | Name of the specific endpoint you want to stream your data.

Must be passed inside the `"endpoint": { }` property. | `standard` | Yes | | url | string | URL to which you want to stream your data.

Must be passed inside the `"endpoint": { }` property. | \- | Yes | | payload_format | string | Defines which information will be sent in your data for each data streaming request.

Must be passed inside the `"endpoint": { }` property. | \- | No | | log_line_separator | string | Defines what information will be used at the end of each log line. Used to break information into different lines.

Must be passed inside the `"endpoint": { }` property. | \- | No | | max_size | int | Defines the size of data packets that will be sent in bytes. Accepts values over 1000000.

Must be passed inside the `"endpoint": { }` property. | ≥ `1000000` | No | | headers | string | Names and values for each header to send to the endpoint.

You can enter one or more custom headers for your HTTP/HTTPS request. Example: `header-name:value`.

Must be passed inside the `"endpoint": { }` property. | \- | No | | domain_ids | int, array | Domain identifiers that you want to associate to the new data streaming. | \- | Yes\*
| | all_domains | bool | Used to associate all domains in your account to the new data streaming.

If you pass this field as `true`, the mandatory parameter `domain_ids` can be passed as an empty list. | `true`
`false` (default) | No\* | > \*Not used with the `rtm_activity` data source.

item.description:
The **Data Streaming API** allows you to manage your existing data streamings and templates.

**Data Streaming** allows you to feed your stream processing, SIEM, and big data platforms with the event logs from your applications on Azion in real time.

See the [reference documentation](https://www.azion.com/en/documentation/products/data-streaming/) for more information.

You can choose from which of the available Azion product and domains you want to collect your logs from and connect it to the endpoint of your data analysis platforms. See the **Domains API** for further details.

You can also decide which data you want to use on your analysis by choosing among the available variables for templates.

item.name: Real-Time Metrics

request.description:
Introspection Queries provide metadata, which are relevant information regarding the scope of data in the Real-Time Metrics API. They can help you understand the relationship and the utility of the request processes.

**Note**: To run the example request, copy the body shown below and paste it on the `data` field.

response.name: Introspection Query

request.description:
Query example that can be applied on the Real-Time Metrics API to query aggregated data provided by your applications. | Property | Type | Description | Accepted values | Required | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | limit | int | Informs the limit of data that'll be exhibited. The default value is `10`. | ≤ `10000` | No | | filter | json | Informs the exact and direct data from your requests.
It's mandatory to inform a `tsRange` OR `tsGt + tsLt`. | `tsRange` OR `tsGt + tsLt` + other filters (optionally) | Yes | | aggregate | json | Informs which consulted data should be exhibited.
You must add an operator (`count`, `sum`, `max`, `min`, or `avg`) + the specific field you want to aggregate data.
If you pass the `aggregate` property, the `groupBy` property is **required**. | count
sum
max
min
avg
\+ field to aggregate | No | | groupBy | string | Informs the fields whose information you want to group.
If you pass the `aggregate` property, the `groupBy` property is **required**. | \- | No | | orderBy | string | Allows you to organize and sort the received data of a dataset according to the event’s order.
You can order data data in ascending order (`ASC`) or descending order (`DESC`). Although ASC is the default sort for all fields in the dataset, you can only use DESC order with the timestamp (TS) field. | \- | No | **Important**: if you pass the `aggregate` property in your query, the `groupBy` property is **required**.

item.description:
The Metrics GraphQL API enables you to consult, modify, and filter aggregated data in different time intervals (minute, hour, and day) taken from the traffic generated by your content and applications through Azion.

---

### About GraphQL

Graphic Query Language (GraphQL) is a language created for use with APIs. It works as an alternative to REST APIs, allowing you to get data according to your needs. GraphQL gives you autonomy to request the data you want and receive exactly what you asked for through a JSON result.

As GraphQL fetches information differently from traditional APIs, it assists you in filtering data without overfetching. The precise response it provides also gives a better performance to those using GraphQL and makes it easier to use. Another difference from other APIs is that it has a single endpoint.

To learn more about specific characteristics of Azion's GraphQL and how to use it, see the [reference documentation page](https://www.azion.com/en/documentation/products/graphql-api).

#### Differences between GraphQL and REST APIs

While using GraphQL, it's also important to note that it presents some practical differences from Azion REST APIs.

GraphQL returns specific Error Responses, detailed in [this documentation page](https://www.azion.com/en/documentation/products/graphql-api-error-responses/).

GraphQL also has its own predetermined limits, detailed in [this documentation page](https://www.azion.com/en/documentation/products/graphql-api-limits/).

item.name: Real-Time Events

request.description:
Introspection Queries provide metadata, which are relevant information regarding the scope of data in the Real-Time Events API. They can help you understand the relationship and the utility of the request processes.

**Note**: To run the example request, copy the body shown below and paste it on the `data` field.

response.name: Introspection Query

request.description:
Query example that can be applied on the Real-Time Events API to query raw data provided by your applications. | Property | Type | Description | Accepted values | Required | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | limit | int | Informs the limit of data that'll be exhibited. The default value is `10`. | ≤ `10000` | No | | filter | json | Informs the exact and direct data from your requests.

You must inform a `tsRange` OR `tsGt + tsLt`. | `tsRange` OR `tsGt + tsLt` + other filters (optionally) | Yes | | aggregate | json | Informs which consulted data should be exhibited.

You must add an operator (`count`, `sum`, `max`, `min`, or `avg`) + the specific field you want to aggregate data.
If you pass the `aggregate` property, the `groupBy` property is **required**. | count
sum
max
min
avg
\+ field to aggregate | No | | groupBy | string | Informs the fields whose information you want to group.

If you pass the `aggregate` property, the `groupBy` property is **required**. | \- | No | | orderBy | string | Allows you to organize and sort the received data of a dataset according to the event’s order.

You can order data in ascending order (`ASC`) or descending order (`DESC`).

Although `ASC` is the default sort for all fields in the dataset, you can only use `DESC` order with the timestamp (`TS`) field. | \- | No | **Important**: if you pass the `aggregate` property in your query, the `groupBy` property is **required**.

item.description:
The Events GraphQL API enables you to consult, modify, and filter raw data taken from the traffic events generated by your content and applications through Azion.

Observe products assist you in monitoring and accessing information related to your data. Each product, along with their features and capabilities, allows you to make the best possible use of your data to enhance your monitoring and user experience.

You can use the Azion APIs for the **Data Streaming**, **Real-Time Metrics** and **Real-Time Events** products.
